017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
018
019import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch;
020import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.glutils.ShaderProgram;
021import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorfulBatch;
023import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorfulSprite;
024
025/**
026 * Shader code to construct a {@link ShaderProgram} that can render the specialized colors produced by the rest of this
027 * library. The shader code is meant for use in a {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch}; a convenience
028 * method, {@link #makeYCwCmBatch()}, is provided to generate and return a SpriteBatch that uses a correct ShaderProgram.
029 * Many of the shaders here are experimental and meant as a basis for user code, rather than a complete solution.
030 * If you aren't familiar with shaders in libGDX, <a href="https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/Shaders">see this
031 * libGDX wiki article</a> for more information.
032 * <br>
033 * None of the shaders here specify a {@code #version}, and some combinations of OS, driver, and GPU hardware may
034 * require the version to be set to a specific value. You may need to put:
035 * {@code ShaderProgram.prependVertexCode = "#version 110\n";
036 * ShaderProgram.prependFragmentCode = "#version 110\n";} in your launchers, with whatever version you can support, in
037 * order to avoid some warnings or errors on some systems.
038 * <br>
039 * Many of these shaders would need at least some changing to work with kinds of
040 * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch} that aren't SpriteBatch (or at least very similar). You should compare
041 * the names of {@code uniform} variables in the vertex and fragment shader if you use a different kind of Batch; if all
042 * of them are the same and there are the same amount, then you should be able to use these shaders without issue.
043 * <br>
044 * Note that you don't need to specify a shader from here at all if you use a ColorfulBatch from this library!
045 * There is a ColorfulBatch in each of the color space subpackages, such as {@code rgb}, {@code oklab}, and {@code ipt}.
046 * All of those allow a multiplicative "tweak" to each color channel before an additive change is applied to that
047 * channel; to contrast, all the shaders here can only permit one or the other for a given channel. ColorfulBatch may
048 * act oddly if it has to interact with SpriteBatch-specific classes like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Sprite},
049 * so there are ColorfulSprite classes that also allow setting the "tweak" and additive change per-sprite. Still, it can
050 * be a good idea to use the shaders here if you have an existing SpriteBatch, or want to use the various experimental
051 * shaders as a test-bed.
052 */
053public class Shaders {
054    /**
055     * This is the default vertex shader from libGDX. It is used without change by most of the fragment shaders here.
056     */
057    public static final String vertexShader = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
058            + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
059            + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
060            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
061            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
062            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
063            + "\n"
064            + "void main()\n"
065            + "{\n"
066            + "   v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
067            + "   v_color.a = v_color.a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
068            + "   v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
069            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
070            + "}\n";
071    /*
072attribute vec4 a_position;
073attribute vec4 a_color;
074attribute vec2 a_texCoord0;
075uniform mat4 u_projTrans;
076varying vec4 v_color;
077varying vec2 v_texCoords;
078
079void main()
080{
081   v_color = a_color;
082   v_color.a = v_color.a * (255.0/254.0);
083   v_texCoords = a_texCoord0;
084   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * a_position;
085}
086     */
087
088    /**
089     * A simple shader that uses additive blending with "normal" RGBA colors (alpha is still multiplicative).
090     * With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram, white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%,
091     * and black darkens a color to black, but nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color,
092     * white adds 0.5 to the RGB channels (brightening it and also desaturating it), and black subtracts 0.5 from the
093     * RGB channels (darkening and desaturating, but not to black unless the color is already somewhat dark). When
094     * tinting with white, this looks like <a href="https://i.imgur.com/yFtgdwz.png">The Mona Lisa on the left</a>, when
095     * tinting with 50% gray, it makes no change, and when tinting with black, it almost reaches all black, but some
096     * part of the image is still visible.
097     * <br>
098     * This is probably the fastest shader here, since it does so little math to compute a brighter or darker color. The
099     * code here changed from a more complex RGBA shader that used pow(), but didn't look different enough from
100     * {@link #fragmentShaderMultiplyRGBA} to warrant having both. Note that the Multiply version can actually reduce an
101     * image's colors to all black, but this version cannot.
102     * <br>
103     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
104     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
105     * <br>
106     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
107     */
108    public static final String fragmentShaderRGBA =
109            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
110                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
111                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
112                    "#else\n" +
113                    "#define LOWP \n" +
114                    "#endif\n" +
115                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
116                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
117                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
118                    "void main()\n" +
119                    "{\n" +
120                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
121                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(tgt.rgb + (v_color.rgb - 0.5), v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
122                    "}";
123
124    /**
125     * Adjusts RGBA colors so the RGB values are exaggerated towards or away from 0.0 or 1.0, depending on a uniform.
126     * This uses a uniform float, 0.0 or greater, called "contrast"; when contrast is 1.0, the image is rendered without
127     * changes, but when it is 0.0, everything will be gray, and if it is greater than 1.0, contrast will be stronger.
128     * <br>
129     * This code was partly written by <a href="https://github.com/SheerSt">SheerSt</a> and partly by tommyettinger,
130     * but this is the type of shader code you see in some tutorials, so hopefully it is easy to read.
131     * <br>
132     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
133     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
134     * <br>
135     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}. Make sure to set the {@code contrast} uniform before using!
136     */
137    public static final String fragmentShaderContrastUniform =
138            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
139                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
140                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
141                    "#else\n" +
142                    "#define LOWP \n" +
143                    "#endif\n" +
144                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
145                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
146                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
147                    "\n" +
148                    "uniform float contrast;\n" +
149                    "\n" +
150                    "void main()\n" +
151                    "{\n" +
152                    "    vec4 color = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
153                    "    color.rgb = clamp((color.rgb - 0.5f) * contrast + 0.5f, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
154                    "    gl_FragColor = color;\n" +
155                    "}";
156    /**
157     * A simple shader that uses multiplicative blending with "normal" RGBA colors, and is simpler than
158     * {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA} but can make changes in color smoother. With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram,
159     * white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%, and black darkens a color to black, but
160     * nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color, white multiplies the RGB channels by
161     * 2.0 (brightening it and slightly desaturating it), and black multiplies the RGB channels by 0 (reducing the color
162     * always to black). When tinting with white, this looks like <a href="https://i.imgur.com/I30jeXv.png">The Mona
163     * Lisa on the left</a>; when tinting with 50% gray, it makes no change, and when tinting with black, it produces an
164     * all-black image.
165     * <br>
166     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
167     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
168     * <br>
169     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
170     * <br>
171     * An earlier version of this attempted to use some useful code by CypherCove in gdx-tween, but the current version
172     * doesn't share any code, and doesn't really do any gamma correction either. It does less... gamma... un-correction
173     * than {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA}, though, so if the source images are gamma-corrected this should be fine.
174     * <br>
175     * This was called {@code fragmentShaderGammaRGBA}, but it doesn't do any gamma-correction now. It still seems quite
176     * smooth. Where {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA} adds the batch color to the pixel colors, this multiplies them.
177     */
178    public static final String fragmentShaderMultiplyRGBA =
179            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
180                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
181                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
182                    "#else\n" +
183                    "#define LOWP \n" +
184                    "#endif\n" +
185                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
186                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
187                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
188                    "void main()\n" +
189                    "{\n" +
190                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n" +
191                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(tgt.rgb * v_color.rgb * 2.0, v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
192                    "}";
193
194
195    /**
196     * A simple shader that uses additive blending with "normal" RGBA colors (alpha is still multiplicative), and
197     * increases contrast somewhat, making the lightness change more sharply or harshly.
198     * With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram, white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%,
199     * and black darkens a color to black, but nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color,
200     * white adds 0.5 to the RGB channels (brightening it and also desaturating it), and black subtracts 0.5 from the
201     * RGB channels (darkening and desaturating, but not to black unless the color is already somewhat dark).
202     * <br>
203     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
204     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
205     * <br>
206     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
207     */
208    public static final String fragmentShaderHigherContrastRGBA =
209            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
210                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
211                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
212                    "#else\n" +
213                    "#define LOWP \n" +
214                    "#endif\n" +
215                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
216                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
217                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
218                    "const float contrast =    1.5   ;\n" +
219                    "vec3 barronSpline(vec3 x, float shape) {\n" +
220                    "        const float turning = 0.5;\n" +
221                    "        vec3 d = turning - x;\n" +
222                    "        return mix(\n" +
223                    "          ((1. - turning) * (x - 1.)) / (1. - (x + shape * d)) + 1.,\n" +
224                    "          (turning * x) / (1.0e-20 + (x + shape * d)),\n" +
225                    "          step(0.0, d));\n" +
226                    "}\n" +
227                    "void main()\n" +
228                    "{\n" +
229                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
230                    "  tgt.rgb = barronSpline(clamp(tgt.rgb + v_color.rgb - 0.5, 0.0, 1.0), contrast);\n" +
231                    "  tgt.a *= v_color.a;\n" +
232                    "  gl_FragColor = tgt;\n" +
233                    "}";
234
235    /**
236     * A simple shader that uses additive blending with "normal" RGBA colors (alpha is still multiplicative), and
237     * reduces contrast somewhat, making the lightness more murky and uniform.
238     * With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram, white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%,
239     * and black darkens a color to black, but nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color,
240     * white adds 0.5 to the RGB channels (brightening it and also desaturating it), and black subtracts 0.5 from the
241     * RGB channels (darkening and desaturating, but not to black unless the color is already somewhat dark).
242     * <br>
243     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
244     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
245     * <br>
246     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
247     */
248    public static final String fragmentShaderLowerContrastRGBA = fragmentShaderHigherContrastRGBA.replace("   1.5   ", "0.5");
249
250    //// save the result as shader, and set it on your batch with
251    // ShaderProgram shader = makeRGBAShader();
252    // batch.setShader(shader)
253    /**
254     * A simple helper method that builds the simplest shader here; this shader allows tinting with light colors to
255     * lighten an image. You can assign the result to a SpriteBatch with its
256     * {@link SpriteBatch#setShader(ShaderProgram)} method.
257     * <br>
258     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
259     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
260     * @return a ShaderProgram that uses the RGBA shader {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA}
261     */
262    public static ShaderProgram makeRGBAShader()
263    {
264        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderRGBA);
265        if(!shader.isCompiled())
266            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
267        return shader;
268    }
269    /**
270     * A simple helper method that builds the simplest shader here; this shader allows tinting with light colors to
271     * lighten an image, and also smooths changes well. You can assign the result to a SpriteBatch with its
272     * {@link SpriteBatch#setShader(ShaderProgram)} method.
273     * <br>
274     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
275     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
276     * <br>
277     * This was called {@code makeGammaRGBAShader}, but because it doesn't currently do any gamma correction, naming it
278     * {@code makeMultiplyRGBAShader} seems more appropriate. {@link #makeRGBAShader()} is the additive counterpart.
279     * @return a ShaderProgram that uses the RGBA shader {@link #fragmentShaderMultiplyRGBA}
280     */
281    public static ShaderProgram makeMultiplyRGBAShader()
282    {
283        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderMultiplyRGBA);
284        if(!shader.isCompiled())
285            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
286        return shader;
287    }
288    /**
289     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShaderHigherContrastRGBA}
290     * from this class, making it able to render RGBA colors from the libGDX or the rgb package. This also takes a
291     * {@code contrast} parameter, which modifies the contrast in the higher-contrast fragment shader; if greater than
292     * 1.0 it will make light colors lighter and dark colors darker, while if it is less than 1.0 it will make all but
293     * the darkest colors closer to the upper-middle-range of lightness. If you want to adjust contrast per-sprite, use
294     * a {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways); you can
295     * simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch like this produces
296     * won't be able to render a {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorfulSprite}, but ColorfulBatch can.
297     * ColorfulBatch also will calculate contrast differently from the shader this uses. It also takes a contrast in its
298     * tweak value that is limited to a 0.0 to 1.0 range, rather than 0.0 on up here. One potential use for this method
299     * is to "deep-fry" a scene's image by using very high contrast (5.0 or higher).
300     * <br>
301     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
302     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
303     * @param contrast how much contrast should be emphasized; higher than 1.0 is more contrasting, and this should usually be between 0.1 and 5.0
304     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering RGB with contrast
305     */
306    public static SpriteBatch makeRGBABatch(final float contrast)
307    {
308        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderHigherContrastRGBA.replace("   1.5   ", Float.toString(Math.max(contrast, 0.0f))));
309        if(!shader.isCompiled())
310            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
311        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
312    }
313
314    /**
315     * Where the magic happens; this converts a batch color from the YCwCm format (used by colorful's ycwcm package) to
316     * RGBA. The vertex color will be split up into 4 channels just as a normal shader does, but the channels here are
317     * luma, chromatic warmth, chromatic mildness, and alpha; alpha acts just like a typical RGBA shader, but the others
318     * are additive instead of multiplicative, with 0.5 as a neutral value. This does not support the "tweak" features
319     * that {@link ColorfulBatch} does, which include multiplicative counterparts to the additive operations this
320     * supports on luma, chromatic warmth, and chromatic mildness, plus a contrast adjustment. If you want to adjust
321     * contrast globally, you can use {@link #makeYCwCmBatch(float)} to set the contrast for a new Batch with a new shader.
322     * <br>
323     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
324     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
325     * <br>
326     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
327     * <br>
328     * This was called {@code fragmentShader}, a name which dates back to when this was the only one in this file. It is
329     * not the only one anymore.
330     */
331    public static final String fragmentShaderYCwCm =
332            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
333                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
334                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
335                    "#else\n" +
336                    "#define LOWP \n" +
337                    "#endif\n" +
338                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
339                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
340                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
341                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125);\n" +
342                    "void main()\n" +
343                    "{\n" +
344                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
345                    "////use the following line to match the color exactly\n" +
346                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r - 0.5 + dot(tgt.rgb, bright), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
347                    "////use the following line to increase contrast\n" +
348                    "//   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r * dot(sin(tgt.rgb * 1.5707963267948966) * sqrt(tgt.rgb), bright), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
349                    "////use the following line to increase contrast more\n" +
350                    "//   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, bright), 1.25), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
351                    //uses a specific matrix (related to bright, above) multiplied with ycc to get back to rgb.
352                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4( (clamp(mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.625, -0.375, -0.375, -0.5, 0.5, -0.5) * ycc, 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
353                    "}";
354    /**
355     * A variant on {@link #fragmentShaderYCwCm} that adjusts luma to make mid-range colors darker, while keeping light
356     * colors light. This is not the same as {@link ColorfulBatch} even when the contrast for ColorfulBatch's tweak is
357     * the same as what this uses (1.375 here, which is roughly 0.875f in a tweak value). ColorfulBatch does some work
358     * in the vertex shader so it may be a little faster than this approach, and it seems to have less severe effects on
359     * the overall brightness of an image that has adjusted contrast.
360     * <br>
361     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
362     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
363     * <br>
364     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
365     */
366    public static final String fragmentShaderHigherContrast =
367            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
368                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
369                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
370                    "#else\n" +
371                    "#define LOWP \n" +
372                    "#endif\n" +
373                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
374                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
375                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
376                    "const float contrast =    1.375   ; // You can make contrast a uniform if you want.\n" +
377                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125) * (4.0 / 3.0);\n" +
378                    "void main()\n" +
379                    "{\n" +
380                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
381                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r - 0.5 + pow(dot(tgt.rgb, bright), contrast) * 0.75, ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
382                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4( (clamp(mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.625, -0.375, -0.375, -0.5, 0.5, -0.5) * ycc, 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
383                    "}";
384
385    /**
386     * An alternative shader that effectively reduces luma contrast, bringing all but the darkest colors to the
387     * upper-mid luma range. This is not the same as {@link ColorfulBatch} even when the contrast for ColorfulBatch's
388     * tweak is the same as what this uses (0.625 here, which is roughly 0.125f in a tweak value). ColorfulBatch does
389     * some work in the vertex shader so it may be a little faster than this approach, and it seems to have less severe
390     * effects on the overall brightness of an image that has adjusted contrast.
391     * <br>
392     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
393     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
394     * <br>
395     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
396     */
397    public static final String fragmentShaderLowerContrast = fragmentShaderHigherContrast.replace("   1.375   ", "0.625");
398
399    /**
400     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses the default {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShaderYCwCm}
401     * from this class, making it able to render YCwCm colors from the ycwcm package. It won't be a
402     * {@link ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways); you can simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to
403     * make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch like this produces won't be able to render a {@link ColorfulSprite},
404     * but ColorfulBatch can.
405     * <br>
406     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
407     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
408     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
409     */
410    public static SpriteBatch makeYCwCmBatch()
411    {
412        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderYCwCm);
413        if(!shader.isCompiled())
414            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
415        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
416    }
417
418    /**
419     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses the default {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShaderYCwCm}
420     * from this class, making it able to render YCwCm colors from the ycwcm package. This also takes a
421     * {@code contrast} parameter; if greater than 1.0 it will make light colors lighter and dark colors darker, while
422     * if it is less than 1.0 it will make all but the darkest colors closer to the upper-middle-range of lightness.
423     * If you want to adjust contrast per-sprite, use a {@link ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways);
424     * you can simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch like this produces
425     * won't be able to render a {@link ColorfulSprite}, but ColorfulBatch can. ColorfulBatch also will calculate
426     * contrast differently from the shader this uses, including doing some work in the vertex shader (which may be
427     * faster). It also takes a contrast in its tweak value that is limited to a 0.0 to 1.0 range, rather than 0.1 to
428     * 2.0 here (this can technically tolerate 0.01 to 10.0, but those extremes aren't recommended).
429     * <br>
430     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
431     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
432     * @param contrast how much contrast should be emphasized; higher than 1.0 is more contrasting, and this should usually be between 0.1 and 2.0
433     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
434     */
435    public static SpriteBatch makeYCwCmBatch(final float contrast)
436    {
437        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderHigherContrast.replace("   1.375   ", Float.toString(Math.min(Math.max(contrast, 0.01f), 10f))));
438        if(!shader.isCompiled())
439            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
440        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
441    }
442
443    /**
444     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses {@link #vertexShaderHSLC} and {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}
445     * from this class, making it interpret the SpriteBatch's color, as set by 
446     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, to be hue rotation, saturation change, lightness
447     * change, and contrast change. All of these are neutral when their value is 0.5f. Hue rotates clockwise or
448     * counterclockwise when it goes toward 0.0, and the other way when it goes toward 1.0; 0.0 and 1.0 both refer to
449     * the 180 degree rotation, but I don't know which goes which way (it also depends on how you visualize hue).
450     * Saturation becomes more grayscale as it goes towards 0.0, and more vivid as it goes towards 1.0. Lightness gets
451     * darker towards 0.0, lighter towards 1.0 (any lightness above 0.5 will brighten the image, unlike the default
452     * shader and batch color). Contrast affects changes in lightness; low contrast makes all lightness closer to the
453     * mid-range, while high contrast makes even small changes in the mid-range of an image's color have stark lightness
454     * changes in the result. Note, this does not support changing an image's alpha with the batch color.
455     * <br>
456     * You can generate HSLC colors using {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}, using the last
457     * parameter to store contrast.
458     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering HSLC
459     */
460    public static SpriteBatch makeBatchHSLC()
461    {
462        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShaderHSLC, fragmentShaderHSLC);
463        if(!shader.isCompiled())
464            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
465        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
466    }
467
468    /**
469     * Similar to {@link #fragmentShaderYCwCm}, but this uses the very perceptually-accurate IPT color space as described by
470     * Ebner and Fairchild, instead of the custom YCwCm color space. IPT doesn't really need that much more computation
471     * to be done by the shader, but tends to make gradual changes in color much smoother. If comparing to YCwCm, then
472     * Y (luma) is like I (intensity) here, so when a Batch color has 0 for I (stored in the r channel), it makes the
473     * image very dark, while if the Batch color has 1 for I, it makes the image very light. Cw and Cm can be graphed
474     * like a color wheel, and in their case, the 4 corners of a square graph are red, yellow, green, and blue. IPT is
475     * less geometrical, and the corners are roughly purple, orange, green, and cyan, while the centers of the edges of
476     * the square are close to red, yellow, green, and blue. <a href="https://i.imgur.com/A3n4qmM.png">See this capture
477     * of the IPT space</a> if you want a better picture. The P (short for protan, a term from ophthalmology) channel
478     * (stored in g) is the left-to-right axis there, with P==0 making colors green or blue (cooler), and P==1 making
479     * colors orange, red, or purple (somewhat warmer). The T (short for tritan, also from ophthalmology) channel
480     * (stored in b) is the down-to-up axis there, with T==0 making colors more blue or purple, and T==1 making colors
481     * more green, yellow, brown, or orange. Where protan can be viewed as going from cool to warm as its value
482     * increases, tritan can be viewed as going from artificial to natural, or perhaps fluid to solid. Alpha is treated
483     * exactly as it is in the standard libGDX fragment shader, with the alpha in the batch color multiplied by the
484     * alpha in the image pixel to get the result alpha.
485     * <br>
486     * You can generate IPT colors using any of various methods in the {@code ipt} package, such as
487     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}. Note that IPT is
488     * intended to share an API with the {@code ipt_hq} package, but IPT_HQ is usually preferred.
489     * <br>
490     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
491     */
492    public static String fragmentShaderIPT =
493            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
494                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
495                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
496                    "#else\n" +
497                    "#define LOWP \n" +
498                    "#endif\n" +
499                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
500                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
501                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
502                    "void main()\n" +
503                    "{\n" +
504                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
505                    "    vec4 adj = v_color;\n" +
506                    "    adj.yz = adj.yz * 2.0 - 0.5;\n" +
507                    "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
508                    "         * (tgt.rgb)) + adj.xyz - 0.5;\n" +
509                    "    ipt.x = clamp(ipt.x, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
510                    "    ipt.yz = clamp(ipt.yz, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
511                    "    vec3 back = mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt;\n" +
512                    "    gl_FragColor = vec4(clamp(back, 0.0, 1.0), adj.a * tgt.a);\n" +
513                    "}";
514    /**
515     * Just like {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}, but gamma-corrects the input and output RGB values (which improves
516     * lightness uniformity) and uses an exponential step internally to change how colors are distributed within the
517     * gamut. These steps are more computationally expensive than the bare-bones ones in {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}, but
518     * they seem to improve some aspects of color transitions quite a bit.
519     * <br>
520     * You can generate IPT_HQ colors using any of various methods in the {@code ipt_hq} package, such as
521     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt_hq.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}. Note that IPT_HQ is
522     * intended to share an API with the {@code ipt} package, but IPT_HQ is usually preferred.
523     * <br>
524     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
525     */
526    public static String fragmentShaderIPT_HQ =
527            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
528                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
529                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
530                    "#else\n" +
531                    "#define LOWP \n" +
532                    "#endif\n" +
533                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
534                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
535                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
536                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(0.43);\n" +
537                    "const vec3 reverse = vec3(1.0 / 0.43);\n" +
538                    "void main()\n" +
539                    "{\n" +
540                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
541                    "  vec3 ipt = mat3(0.40000, 4.45500, 0.80560, 0.40000, -4.8510, 0.35720, 0.20000, 0.39600, -1.1628) *" +
542                    "             pow(mat3(0.313921, 0.151693, 0.017753, 0.639468, 0.748209, 0.109468, 0.0465970, 0.1000044, 0.8729690) \n" +
543                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
544                    "  ipt.x = clamp(ipt.x + v_color.x - 0.55, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
545                    "  ipt.yz = clamp(ipt.yz + v_color.yz * 2.0 - 1.0, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
546                    "  ipt = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.097569, -0.11388, 0.032615, 0.205226, 0.133217, -0.67689) * ipt;\n" +
547                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
548                    "                 mat3(5.432622, -1.10517, 0.028104, -4.67910, 2.311198, -0.19466, 0.246257, -0.20588, 1.166325) *\n" +
549                    "                 (sign(ipt) * pow(abs(ipt), reverse))," +
550                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
551                    "}";
552
553    /**
554     * Just like {@link #fragmentShaderIPT_HQ}, but uses the Oklab color space instead of the very similar IPT_HQ one.
555     * This also gamma-corrects the inputs and outputs, though it uses subtly different math internally. Oklab colors
556     * tend to have more variation on their L channel, which represents lightness, than their A or B channels, which
557     * represent green-to-red and blue-to-yellow chromatic axes; indeed, A and B tend to be no more than about 1/6 away
558     * from their middle point at 1/2, which is used for grayscale. This is normal for Oklab, and allows colors to be
559     * compared for approximate difference using Euclidean distance. Importantly, Oklab preserves the meaning of its L
560     * channel (lightness) very well when comparing two arbitrary colors, while also doing well when comparing chroma
561     * (see {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools#chroma(float)}.
562     * <br>
563     * You can generate Oklab colors using any of various methods in the {@code oklab} package, such as
564     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}.
565     * <br>
566     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
567     */
568    public static String fragmentShaderOklab =
569            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
570                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
571                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
572                    "#else\n" +
573                    "#define LOWP \n" +
574                    "#endif\n" +
575                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
576                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
577                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
578                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n" +
579                    "float toOklab(float L) {\n" +
580                    "        const float shape = 0.64516133, turning = 0.95;\n" +
581                    "        float d = turning - L;\n" +
582                    "        float r = mix(\n" +
583                    "          ((1. - turning) * (L - 1.)) / (1. - (L + shape * d)) + 1.,\n" +
584                    "          (turning * L) / (1.0e-20 + (L + shape * d)),\n" +
585                    "          step(0.0, d));\n" +
586                    "        return r * r;\n" +
587                    "}\n" +
588                    "float fromOklab(float L) {\n" +
589                    "        const float shape = 1.55, turning = 0.95;\n" +
590                    "        L = sqrt(L);\n" +
591                    "        float d = turning - L;\n" +
592                    "        return mix(\n" +
593                    "          ((1. - turning) * (L - 1.)) / (1. - (L + shape * d)) + 1.,\n" +
594                    "          (turning * L) / (1.0e-20 + (L + shape * d)),\n" +
595                    "          step(0.0, d));\n" +
596                    "}\n" +
597//                    "float toOklab(float L) {\n" +
598//                    "  return (L - 1.0) / (1.0 - L * 0.4285714) + 1.0;\n" +
599//                    "}\n" +
600//                    "float fromOklab(float L) {\n" +
601//                    "  return (L - 1.0) / (1.0 + L * 0.75) + 1.0;\n" +
602//                    "}\n" +
603                    "void main()\n" +
604                    "{\n" +
605                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
606                    "  vec3 lab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *" +
607                    "             pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n" +
608                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
609                    "  lab.x = fromOklab(clamp(toOklab(lab.x) + v_color.r - 0.5, 0.0, 1.0));\n" +
610                    "  lab.yz = clamp(lab.yz + v_color.gb * 2.0 - 1.0, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
611                    "  lab = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, +0.3963377774, -0.1055613458, -0.0894841775, +0.2158037573, -0.0638541728, -1.2914855480) * lab;\n" +
612                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
613                    "                 mat3(+4.0767245293, -1.2681437731, -0.0041119885, -3.3072168827, +2.6093323231, -0.7034763098, +0.2307590544, -0.3411344290, +1.7068625689) *\n" +
614                    "                 (lab * lab * lab)," +
615                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
616                    "}";
617
618    /**
619     * A vertex shader that does the bulk of processing HSI-format batch colors and converting them to a format
620     * {@link #fragmentShaderHSI} can use. Since HSI is only a cylindrical/spherical adaptation of IPT, with identical
621     * I components and the combination of H and S in polar coordinates mapping to P and T in Cartesian coordinates,
622     * the fragment shader this is used with can be any that expects an IPT color (currently only
623     * {@link #fragmentShaderIPT} does this, and it's the same as {@link #fragmentShaderHSI}). This vertex shader does
624     * a lot more than most vertex shaders here, but since it is executed relatively rarely (unless you're drawing many
625     * 1-pixel textures), there shouldn't be a heavy performance penalty.
626     * <br>
627     * There is no special code to generate HSI colors; you can use
628     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, or any ColorTools
629     * method that generates a packed float color directly from the channel values, to specify hue, saturation,
630     * intensity, and alpha in that order. You can also just specify the batch color directly with
631     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, taking the channels in the same order as above.
632     * <br>
633     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
634     */
635    public static final String vertexShaderHSI = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
636        + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
637        + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
638        + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
639        + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
640        + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
641        + "const vec3 yellow  = vec3( 0.16155326,0.020876605,-0.26078433 );\n"
642        + "const vec3 magenta = vec3(-0.16136102,0.122068435,-0.070396   );\n"
643        + "const vec3 cyan    = vec3( 0.16420607,0.3481738,   0.104959644);\n"
644        + "void main()\n"
645        + "{\n"
646        + "    v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
647        + "    v_color.a = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ".a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
648        + "    vec3 hsi = v_color.rgb;\n"
649        + "    v_color.x = (hsi.z - 0.5) * 0.9999;\n"
650        + "    hsi.x *= 6.28318;\n"
651        + "    hsi.y *= 0.5;\n"
652        + "    v_color.y = cos(hsi.x) * hsi.y;\n"
653        + "    v_color.z = sin(hsi.x) * hsi.y;\n"
654        + "    float crMid = dot(cyan.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
655        + "    float mgMid = dot(magenta.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
656        + "    float ybMid = dot(yellow.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
657        + "    float crScale = (v_color.x - 0.5 + step(crMid, 0.0)) * cyan.x / (0.00001 - crMid);\n"
658        + "    float mgScale = (v_color.x + 0.5 - step(mgMid, 0.0)) * magenta.x / (0.00001 - mgMid);\n"
659        + "    float ybScale = (v_color.x - 0.5 + step(ybMid, 0.0)) * yellow.x / (0.00001 - ybMid);\n"
660        + "    float scale = 4.0 * min(crScale, min(mgScale, ybScale));\n"
661        + "    v_color.yz *= scale * length(v_color.yz) / cos(3.14159 * v_color.x);\n"
662        + "    v_color.xyz += 0.5;\n"
663        + "    v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
664        + "    gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
665        + "}\n";
666    /**
667     * This is an alias for {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}. If used with {@link #vertexShaderHSI}, you can specify a batch
668     * color using an HSL-like system.
669     * <br>
670     * There is no special code to generate HSI colors; you can use
671     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, or any ColorTools
672     * method that generates a packed float color directly from the channel values, to specify hue, saturation,
673     * intensity, and alpha in that order. You can also just specify the batch color directly with
674     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, taking the channels in the same order as above.
675     * <br>
676     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShaderHSI}.
677     */
678    public static String fragmentShaderHSI = fragmentShaderIPT;
679
680    /**
681     * Not a full shader, this is a snippet used by most of the other HSL-based shaders to implement the complex
682     * rgb2hsl() and hsl2rgb() methods. There are also comments in the code snippet that you can use if you want to
683     * change the distribution of colors across the color wheel.
684     * <br>
685     * <a href="https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/a/59808">Credit to Sam Hocevar</a>.
686     * <br>
687     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
688     */
689    public static final String partialCodeHSL =
690                    "const float eps = 1.0e-10;\n" +
691                    "////Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a\n" +
692                    "////different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).\n" +
693                    "//float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
694                    "//    return  hue * (  2.137\n" +
695                    "//          + hue * (  0.542\n" +
696                    "//          + hue * (-15.141\n" +
697                    "//          + hue * ( 30.120\n" +
698                    "//          + hue * (-22.541\n" +
699                    "//          + hue *   5.883)))));\n" +
700                    "//}\n" +
701                    "////Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a\n" +
702                    "////different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).\n" +
703                    "//float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
704                    "//    return  hue * (  0.677\n" +
705                    "//          + hue * ( -0.123\n" +
706                    "//          + hue * (-11.302\n" +
707                    "//          + hue * ( 46.767\n" +
708                    "//          + hue * (-58.493\n" +
709                    "//          + hue *   23.474)))));\n" +
710                    "//}\n" +
711                    "vec4 rgb2hsl(vec4 c)\n" +
712                    "{\n" +
713                    "    const vec4 J = vec4(0.0, -1.0 / 3.0, 2.0 / 3.0, -1.0);\n" +
714                    "    vec4 p = mix(vec4(c.bg, J.wz), vec4(c.gb, J.xy), step(c.b, c.g));\n" +
715                    "    vec4 q = mix(vec4(p.xyw, c.r), vec4(c.r, p.yzx), step(p.x, c.r));\n" +
716                    "    float d = q.x - min(q.w, q.y);\n" +
717                    "    float l = q.x * (1.0 - 0.5 * d / (q.x + eps));\n" +
718                    "    return vec4(abs(q.z + (q.w - q.y) / (6.0 * d + eps)), (q.x - l) / (min(l, 1.0 - l) + eps), l, c.a);\n" +
719                    "}\n" +
720                    "\n" +
721                    "vec4 hsl2rgb(vec4 c)\n" +
722                    "{\n" +
723                    "    const vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);\n" +
724                    "    vec3 p = abs(fract(c.x + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);\n" +
725                    "    float v = (c.z + c.y * min(c.z, 1.0 - c.z));\n" +
726                    "    return vec4(v * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), 2.0 * (1.0 - c.z / (v + eps))), c.w);\n" +
727                    "}";
728
729    /**
730     * Adjusted-hue version of {@link #partialCodeHSL}, supplying HSL to-and-from RGB conversions with a smaller range
731     * of hue used for cyan and a larger range for orange. Not currently used. This is pretty much only meant so people
732     * reading the source code and trying different variations on HSL can see some of the attempts I made.
733     * <br>
734     * Credit to Sam Hocevar, https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/a/59808 .
735     * <br>
736     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
737     */
738    public static final String partialCodeHSLStretched =
739            "const float eps = 1.0e-10;\n" +
740                    //// maybe not blue enough?
741//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
742//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
743//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
744//                    "    return  hue * (  1.630\n" +
745//                    "          + hue * (  5.937\n" +
746//                    "          + hue * (-38.485\n" +
747//                    "          + hue * ( 76.101\n" +
748//                    "          + hue * (-63.977\n" +
749//                    "          + hue *   19.794)))));\n" +
750//                    "}\n" +
751//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
752//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
753//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
754//                    "    return  hue * (  1.463\n" +
755//                    "          + hue * ( -9.834\n" +
756//                    "          + hue * ( 31.153\n" +
757//                    "          + hue * (-35.066\n" +
758//                    "          + hue *   13.284))));\n" +
759//                    "}\n" +
760                    //// still weirdly high orange
761//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
762//                    "    return  hue * (  2.634\n" +
763//                    "          + hue * ( -4.703\n" +
764//                    "          + hue * (  3.659\n" +
765//                    "          + hue * (  0.829\n" +
766//                    "          + hue *   -1.419))));\n" +
767//                    "}\n" +
768//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
769//                    "    return  hue * (  1.163\n" +
770//                    "          + hue * ( -7.102\n" +
771//                    "          + hue * ( 22.709\n" +
772//                    "          + hue * (-25.502\n" +
773//                    "          + hue *    9.732))));\n" +
774//                    "}\n" +
775//                    "const float ROOT   = 16.0;\n" +
776//                    "const float SQUARE = ROOT * ROOT;\n" +
777                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
778//                    "    return (sqrt(hue * 0.9375 + 0.0625) - 0.25) * 1.333;\n" +
779//                    "    return asin(sqrt(hue * SQUARE) * (1.0 / ROOT)) * (2.0 * 3.14159274);\n" +
780
781//                    "    return asin((sqrt(hue * 0.9375 + 0.0625) - 0.25) * 2.666 - 1.0) * 0.318309886 + 0.5;\n" +
782
783//                    "    return sqrt(sin((hue - 0.5) * 3.14159274) * 0.5 + 0.5);\n" +
784//                    "    return pow(hue, 0.5625);\n" +
785//                    "    return sqrt(hue);\n" +
786                    "    return (sqrt(hue + 0.050625) - 0.225) * 1.25;\n" +
787                    "}\n" +
788                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
789//                    "    hue = sin((hue) * (0.5 * 3.14159274));\n" +
790//                    "    hue = (hue) * 0.75 + 0.25;\n" +
791                    
792//                    "    hue = sin((hue - 0.5) * 3.14159274);\n" +
793//                    "    hue = (hue + 1.0) * 0.375 + 0.25;\n" +
794//                    "    return (hue * hue - 0.0625) * (1.0 / 0.9375);\n" +
795                    
796//                    "    return asin(hue * hue * 2.0 - 1.0) * 0.318309886 + 0.5;\n" +
797//                    "    return pow(hue, 1.77777);\n" +
798                    "    return pow(hue * 0.8 + 0.225, 2.0) - 0.050625;\n" +
799//                    "    return hue * hue;\n" +
800
801//                    "    hue = sin((hue) * (0.5 * 3.14159274));\n" +
802//                    "    hue = hue * ROOT;\n" +
803//                    "    return (hue * hue) * (1.0 / SQUARE);\n" +
804
805                    "}\n" +
806                    //// way too much orange?
807//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
808//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
809//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
810//                    "    return  hue * (  2.137\n" +
811//                    "          + hue * (  0.542\n" +
812//                    "          + hue * (-15.141\n" +
813//                    "          + hue * ( 30.120\n" +
814//                    "          + hue * (-22.541\n" +
815//                    "          + hue *    5.883)))));\n" +
816//                    "}\n" +
817//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
818//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
819//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
820//                    "    return  hue * (  0.677\n" +
821//                    "          + hue * ( -0.123\n" +
822//                    "          + hue * (-11.302\n" +
823//                    "          + hue * ( 46.767\n" +
824//                    "          + hue * (-58.493\n" +
825//                    "          + hue *   23.474)))));\n" +
826//                    "}\n" +
827                    "vec4 rgb2hsl(vec4 c)\n" +
828                    "{\n" +
829                    "    const vec4 J = vec4(0.0, -1.0 / 3.0, 2.0 / 3.0, -1.0);\n" +
830                    "    vec4 p = mix(vec4(c.bg, J.wz), vec4(c.gb, J.xy), step(c.b, c.g));\n" +
831                    "    vec4 q = mix(vec4(p.xyw, c.r), vec4(c.r, p.yzx), step(p.x, c.r));\n" +
832                    "\n" +
833                    "    float d = q.x - min(q.w, q.y);\n" +
834                    "    float l = q.x * (1.0 - 0.5 * d / (q.x + eps));\n" +
835                    "    return vec4(official2primaries(abs(q.z + (q.w - q.y) / (6.0 * d + eps))), (q.x - l) / (min(l, 1.0 - l) + eps), l, c.a);\n" +
836                    "}\n" +
837                    "\n" +
838                    "vec4 hsl2rgb(vec4 c)\n" +
839                    "{\n" +
840                    "    const vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);\n" +
841                    "    vec3 p = abs(fract(primaries2official(c.x) + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);\n" +
842                    "    float v = (c.z + c.y * min(c.z, 1.0 - c.z));\n" +
843                    "    return vec4(v * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), 2.0 * (1.0 - c.z / (v + eps))), c.w);\n" +
844                    "}";
845    /**
846     * This GLSL snippet takes an RGB vec3 and a float that represents a hue rotation in radians, and returns the
847     * rotated RGB vec3. It is not a full shader, and is used by inserting it into shader code to provide the applyHue()
848     * method to that code.
849     * <br>
850     * Credit for this challenging method goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
851     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
852     */
853    public static final String partialHueRodrigues =
854            "vec3 applyHue(vec3 rgb, float hue)\n" +
855                    "{\n" +
856                    "    vec3 k = vec3(0.57735);\n" +
857                    "    float c = cos(hue);\n" +
858                    "    //Rodrigues' rotation formula\n" +
859                    "    return rgb * c + cross(k, rgb) * sin(hue) + k * dot(k, rgb) * (1.0 - c);\n" +
860                    "}\n";
861
862
863    /**
864     * Treats the color as hue, saturation, lightness, and... uh... well, this is pretty much only useful when the batch
865     * color's {@code a} is 1 . You probably want {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} or {@link #fragmentShaderHSLA}.
866     * <br>
867     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
868     */
869    public static final String fragmentShaderHSL =
870            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
871                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
872                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
873                    "#else\n" +
874                    "#define LOWP \n" +
875                    "#endif\n" +
876                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
877                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
878                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
879                    partialCodeHSL +
880                    "void main()\n" +
881                    "{\n" +
882                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
883                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
884                    "   hsl.x = fract((fract(v_color.x + 0.5 - hsl.x) - 0.5) * v_color.w + hsl.x);\n" +
885                    "   hsl.yz = mix(hsl.yz, v_color.yz, v_color.w);\n" +
886                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
887                    "}";
888
889    /**
890     * I can't even remember what this does, to be honest. It's probably not what you want. Instead, you probably want
891     * {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} or {@link #fragmentShaderHSLA}.
892     * <br>
893     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
894     */
895    public static final String fragmentShaderRotateHSL =
896            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
897                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
898                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
899                    "#else\n" +
900                    "#define LOWP \n" +
901                    "#endif\n" +
902                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
903                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
904                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
905                    partialCodeHSL +
906                    "void main()\n" +
907                    "{\n" +
908                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
909                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
910                    "   hsl.x = fract(v_color.x + hsl.x + 0.5);\n" +
911                    "   hsl.yz = clamp(hsl.yz * v_color.yz * 2.0, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
912                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
913                    "}";
914
915    /**
916     * This is similar to the default vertex shader from libGDX, but also sets a varying value for contrast. It is
917     * needed if you use {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}.
918     */
919    public static final String vertexShaderHSLC = "attribute vec4 a_position;\n"
920            + "attribute vec4 a_color;\n"
921            + "attribute vec2 a_texCoord0;\n"
922            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
923            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
924            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" 
925            + "varying float v_lightFix;\n"
926            + "\n"
927            + "void main()\n"
928            + "{\n"
929            + "   v_color = a_color;\n"
930            + "   v_texCoords = a_texCoord0;\n"
931            + "   v_color.a = pow(v_color.a * (255.0/254.0) + 0.5, 1.709);\n"    
932            + "   v_lightFix = 1.0 + pow(v_color.a, 1.41421356);\n"
933            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * a_position;\n"
934            + "}\n";
935
936    /**
937     * Allows changing Hue/Saturation/Lightness/Contrast, with hue as a rotation. If hue continuously goes from 0 to 1,
938     * then 0 to 1, 0 to 1, and so on, then this will smoothly rotate the hue of the image.
939     * <br>
940     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
941     * <br>
942     * Credit for HLSL version goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
943     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
944     * The YCC adaptation, and different approach to contrast (this has close to neutral contrast when a is 0.5,
945     * while the original had a fair bit higher contrast than expected), is from this codebase.
946     * <br>
947     * Meant only for use with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so contrast can
948     * use it.
949     */
950    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC = 
951                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
952                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
953                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
954                    "#else\n" +
955                    "#define LOWP \n" +
956                    "#endif\n" +
957                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
958                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
959                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
960                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
961                            partialHueRodrigues +
962                    "void main()\n" +
963                    "{\n" +
964                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
965                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
966                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
967                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
968                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
969                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
970                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix + brightness),\n" + // lightness
971                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
972                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
973                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
974                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
975                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
976                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
977                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
978                    "}";
979    /**
980     * Allows changing Hue/Saturation/Lightness/Alpha, with hue as a rotation.
981     * <br>
982     * You can generate HSLA colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
983     * <br>
984     * Credit for HLSL version goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
985     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
986     * The YCC adaptation, and change to use alpha, is from this codebase.
987     * <br>
988     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShader}, unlike what {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} expects.
989     */
990    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLA = 
991                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
992                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
993                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
994                    "#else\n" +
995                    "#define LOWP \n" +
996                    "#endif\n" +
997                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
998                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
999                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1000                            partialHueRodrigues +
1001                    "void main()\n" +
1002                    "{\n" +
1003                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
1004                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
1005                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
1006                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1007                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
1008                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
1009                    "     (dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)) + brightness),\n" + // lightness
1010                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
1011                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
1012                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
1013                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
1014                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
1015                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
1016                    "     tgt.a * v_color.w), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
1017                    "}";
1018    /**
1019     * Generally a lower-quality hue rotation than {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}; this is here as a work in progress.
1020     * <br>
1021     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
1022     * <br>
1023     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so
1024     * contrast can use it.
1025     * <br>
1026     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
1027     */
1028    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC2 = 
1029                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1030                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1031                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1032                    "#else\n" +
1033                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1034                    "#endif\n" +
1035                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1036                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
1037                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1038                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1039                            partialCodeHSL +
1040                    "void main()\n" +
1041                    "{\n" +
1042                    "    float hue = (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
1043                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
1044                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
1045                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1046                    "    tgt = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
1047                    "    tgt.r = fract(tgt.r + hue);\n" +
1048                    "    tgt = hsl2rgb(tgt);\n" +
1049                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
1050                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix + brightness),\n" + // lightness
1051                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
1052                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
1053                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
1054                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
1055                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
1056                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
1057                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
1058                    "}";
1059    /**
1060     * Cycles lightness in a psychedelic way as hue and lightness change; not a general-purpose usage.
1061     * <br>
1062     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
1063     * <br>
1064     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so
1065     * contrast can use it.
1066     * <br>
1067     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
1068     */
1069    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC3 =
1070            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1071                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1072                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1073                    "#else\n" +
1074                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1075                    "#endif\n" +
1076                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1077                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
1078                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1079                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1080                    partialHueRodrigues +
1081                    "void main()\n" +
1082                    "{\n" +
1083                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
1084                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
1085                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
1086                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1087                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
1088                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
1089                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix),\n" + // lightness
1090                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
1091                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
1092                    "    tgt.r = sin((tgt.r + brightness) * 6.2831853) * 0.5 + 0.5;\n" +
1093                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
1094                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
1095                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
1096                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
1097                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
1098                    "}";
1099    /**
1100     * Cycles hue, but not lightness; otherwise this is like {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC3} without contrast, and keeping
1101     * alpha intact. Internally, this uses Sam Hocevar's RGB/HSL conversion instead of Andrey-Postelzhuk's HSLC code.
1102     * <br>
1103     * You can generate HSLA colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
1104     * <br>
1105     * Expects the vertex shader to be {@link #vertexShader}, not the HSLC variant.
1106     * <br>
1107     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
1108     */
1109    public static final String fragmentShaderHSL4 =
1110            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1111                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1112                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1113                    "#else\n" +
1114                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1115                    "#endif\n" +
1116                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1117                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1118                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1119                    partialCodeHSL +
1120                    "void main()\n" +
1121                    "{\n" +
1122                    "    float hue = v_color.x - 0.5;\n" +
1123                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
1124                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
1125                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1126                    "    tgt = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
1127                    "    tgt.x = fract(tgt.x + hue);\n" +
1128                    "    tgt.y = clamp(tgt.y * saturation, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1129                    "    tgt.z = clamp(brightness + tgt.z, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1130                    "    gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(tgt);\n" +
1131                    "}";
1132
1133    /**
1134     * One of the more useful HSL shaders here, this takes a batch color as hue, saturation, lightness, and power,
1135     * with hue as a target hue and power used to determine how much of the target color should be used. There is no
1136     * neutral value for hue, saturation, or lightness, but if power is 0, then the source color will be used
1137     * exactly. On the other hand, if power is 1.0, then all pixels will be the target color. Hue is specified from
1138     * 0.0 to 1.0, with 0.0 as red, about 0.3 as green, about 0.6 as blue, etc. Saturation is specified from 0.0 to 1.0,
1139     * with 0.0 as grayscale and 1.0 as a fully-saturated target color. Lightness is specified from 0.0 to 1.0, with 0.0
1140     * as black, the 0.3 to 0.7 range as most colors, and 1.0 white; saturation is clamped to a smaller value as
1141     * lightness moves away from 0.5 (toward black or white).
1142     * <br>
1143     * Expects the vertex shader to be {@link #vertexShader}, not the HSLC variant.
1144     * <br>
1145     * You can generate HSL(P) colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
1146     */
1147    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLP =
1148            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1149                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1150                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1151                    "#else\n" +
1152                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1153                    "#endif\n" +
1154                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1155                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1156                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1157                    partialCodeHSL +
1158                    "void main()\n" +
1159                    "{\n" +
1160                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1161                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
1162                    "   hsl.x *= 6.2831853;\n" +
1163                    "   hsl.xy = vec2(cos(hsl.x), sin(hsl.x)) * hsl.y;\n" +
1164                    "   vec3 tint = vec3(cos(v_color.x * 6.2831853) * v_color.y, sin(v_color.x * 6.2831853) * v_color.y * 2.0, v_color.z);\n" +
1165                    "   hsl.xyz = mix(hsl.xyz, tint, v_color.w);\n" +
1166                    "   hsl.xy = vec2(fract(atan(hsl.y, hsl.x) / 6.2831853), length(hsl.xy));\n" +
1167                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
1168                    "}";
1169
1170    /**
1171     * This is supposed to look for RGBA colors that are similar to {@code search}, and if it finds
1172     * one, to replace it with {@code replace} (also an RGBA color). It isn't great at the searching part.
1173     * <br>
1174     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1175     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1176     * <br>
1177     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
1178     */
1179    public static final String fragmentShaderReplacement = 
1180                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1181                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1182                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1183                    "#else\n" +
1184                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1185                    "#endif\n" +
1186                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1187                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1188                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1189                    "uniform vec4 u_search;\n" +
1190                    "uniform vec4 u_replace;\n" +
1191                    "void main()\n" +
1192                    "{\n" +
1193                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n" +
1194                    "   float curve = smoothstep(0.0, 1.0, 1.25 - distance(tgt.rgb, u_search.rgb) * 2.0);\n" +
1195                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4(mix(tgt.rgb, u_replace.rgb, curve), tgt.a) * v_color;\n" +
1196                    "}";
1197    /**
1198     * A drop-in replacement for the default fragment shader that eliminates lightness differences in the output colors.
1199     * Specifically, it does the normal SpriteBatch shader's step with the multiplicative batch color, converts to IPT,
1200     * sets intensity to 0.5, shrinks the P and T components so the color is less saturated, and then converts back to
1201     * an RGBA color. Even though this uses IPT internally, it expects the batch color to be normal RGBA.
1202     * <br>
1203     * Editing this shader is strongly encouraged to fit your needs!
1204     * <br>
1205     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1206     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1207     * <br>
1208     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
1209     * @see #fragmentShaderConfigurableContrast a per-sprite-configurable version of this
1210     */
1211    public static String fragmentShaderFlatLightness =
1212  "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1213  "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1214  "precision mediump float;\n" +
1215  "#else\n" +
1216  "#define LOWP \n" +
1217  "#endif\n" +
1218  "#define TARGET_LIGHTNESS 0.5 \n" +
1219  "#define SATURATION_CHANGE 1.0 \n" +
1220  "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1221  "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1222  "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1223  "void main()\n" +
1224  "{\n" +
1225  "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1226  "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
1227  "         * (tgt.rgb * v_color.rgb));\n" +
1228  "    ipt.x = TARGET_LIGHTNESS;\n" + // change to desired lightness or pass in a lightness as a uniform
1229  "//    ipt.x = (ipt.x - 0.5) * 0.25 + TARGET_LIGHTNESS;\n" + // an alternative way that preserves a tiny bit of original lightness
1230  "    ipt.yz *= SATURATION_CHANGE;\n" + // multiplies saturation by SATURATION_CHANGE, which may be more or less than 1.0
1231  "    vec3 back = clamp(mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1232  "    gl_FragColor = vec4(back, v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
1233  "}";
1234    /**
1235     * A specialized shader that can reduce lightness differences in the output colors, saturate/desaturate them, and
1236     * can be configured to use some of the existing lightness in the image to add to a main flat lightness.
1237     * Specifically, it takes the fragment color (typically a pixel in a texture), converts to IPT, does a calculation
1238     * involving the intensity of the fragment color where the batch color's blue channel affects how much that
1239     * intensity is used, adds the red channel of the batch color, multiplies the P and T components by the green
1240     * channel times 2.0 to saturate or desaturate, and then converts back to an RGBA color. The neutral value for this
